prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Venue of pending actions

para.paratext: The venue of actions pending and subject to transfer by the Panel is a very important factor in determining where the Panel may transfer actions in any given case. The venue of the actions affects the selection of a transferee district in two ways: the Panel will not normally transfer actions to a district in which no action is then pending and the Panel clearly considers the number of actions pending in various districts to determine the selection. The Panel routinely mentions in its decision that it is selecting a transferee district where at least one action is pending.[1]

Although the Panel is not bound to transfer actions to a district where an action or actions are already pending, the Panel has expressed its reluctance to transfer actions to a district where no actions are pending.[2] The preference for a district in which an action is pending is noticeable. The Panel has stated it is “extremely reluctant to select a district in which no related action is pending” as a transferee district.[3] In one case the Panel noted that discovery would focus in any of six states or geographic areas and ordered transfer to the only such state in which actions were pending.[4] In another case the Panel noted that the District of Columbia would be the most logical transferee district because the federal government offices in Washington would be one clear focus of pretrial proceedings. Because no action had been filed in the District, however, the Panel transferred the 30 actions to the District of Maryland inasmuch as it was the closest district in which an action was pending.[5] The Panel has only rarely transferred cases to a district where no action was pending at the time of transfer.[6] Where no actions are currently pending, the Panel may look to the pendency of a potential tag-along action as a reason to select a transferee district.[7]

The number of actions pending in various districts is a factor less clearly involved in many transfer decisions. If a majority of cases pend in a single district, the Panel will give that fact great consideration and is apt to transfer a few cases pending in other districts to that district.[8] A significant number of pending cases—without regard to it being a majority—will be mentioned by the Panel in selection of the transferee district.[9] This factor may become more important if the potential transferee districts are otherwise comparable.[10] The Panel has indicated that this factor is significant since it reflects the choice of the plaintiffs in each case.[11]

A defendant seeking transfer to a district where no action is pending has an uphill fight.[12] The Panel also sometimes refers to the fact that the cases are pending in that district, focusing more on the ease of administration aspect of this factor.[13] As a practical matter, the fewest actions need be transferred if the Panel selects the transferee district where the largest number of actions are pending.

The Panel considers where the actions are pending at the time transfer is being considered by it. The Panel has specifically considered the current venue of actions that have been transferred under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) in making its decision.[14] Just as the district where the actions are filed reflects the desires of the plaintiffs, the location to which actions are transferred under § 1404(a) reflects the judgment of trial judges as to where trial should take place.[15] For both reasons the venue of the actions at the time the transfer motion is considered by the Panel is a very important factor in determining what transferee district is most appropriate.

Occasionally the venue has an impact on selection of the transferee district by proximity. In considering the venue of pending actions, actions in districts nearby a potential transferee district may be considered by the Panel.[16]

In addition to considering the venue of pending cases, the Panel has also considered the probable venue of future cases. In one decision concerning a group of product liability actions, the Panel selected the District of Colorado as the transferee district for the reason, among others, that the product involved had been test marketed in Denver and therefore that additional actions were expected to be filed in that district.[17] That district was also the venue of the majority of actions already filed. The Panel has also considered the likelihood of additional actions being filed as a factor in determining whether to order transfer.[18]

As the Panel considers venue of pending actions, one action draws particular attention in the Panel's decisions: the first action filed. In traditional venue analysis, the the first-filed action is accorded some deference as establishing the presumptive venue for the litigation, and there may be vestiges of that deference in the Panel's decisions. In all likelihood, however, the strongest reason for the Panel's paying attention to this factor is not deference to the choice of the winner of a race to the courthouse so much as the assumption that the first-filed case may be the most advanced in terms of case management. Cases discussing first-filed case status are collected in § 6:16.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Michaels Stores, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Monsanto Co. Genetically-Engineered Wheat Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Loestrin 24 Fe Antitrust Litigation, 2013 WL 5505369 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re National Football League Players' Concussion Injury Litigation, 842 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Apple IPhone 3G and 3GS “MMS” Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Battlefield Waste Disposal Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Cheerios Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Vertrue Inc. Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1318 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Cathode Ray Tube (CRT) Antitrust Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Long Beach Mortg. Co. Truth in Lending Act 1-4 Family Rider Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Stand 'n Seal Products, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Circular Thermostat Antitrust Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Ace Ltd. Securities Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Community Bank of Northern Virginia Mortgage Lending Practices Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Compression Labs, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re USF Red Star Inc. Workers Notification Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Maytag Corp. Neptune Washer Products Liability Litigation, 333 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Mush Cay Litigation, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

See, e.g., In re Ownership of Longoria Bank Deposits Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 913, 916 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 406 F. Supp. 540, 542 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Uranium Contracts Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 316, 319 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478, 479 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Papeete, Tahiti, on July 22, 1973, 397 F. Supp. 886 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Crash Disaster at Pago Pago, Am. Samoa, on January 30, 1974, 383 F. Supp. 501 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
See In re Air Crash Disaster Near Papeete, Tahiti, on July 22, 1973, 397 F. Supp. 886, 887 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
In re Air Crash Disaster at Covington, Ky., on June 2, 1983, 579 F. Supp. 1057, 1058 (J.P.M.L. 1984).

See In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240, 1243 (J.P.M.L. 1977); see also In re LandAmerica 1031 Exchange Services, Inc., Internal Revenue Service § 1031 Tax Deferred Exchange Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (transfer ordered to district with pending action closest to location of headquarters of central defendant); In re Human Tissue Products Liability Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (transfer to district with pending action closest to district where criminal proceedings pend); In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic “Cleocin” Products Liability Litigation, 450 F. Supp. 1168, 1171 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478, 480 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (District of Columbia selected for similar reasons).

See, e.g., In re Bard IVC Filters Products Liability Litigation, 122 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re GAF Elk Cross Timbers Decking Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1407 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Pella Corp. Architect and Designer Series Windows Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 996 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Subway Footlong Sandwich Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 949 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013); In re: Biomet M2a Magnum Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 896 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Webvention LLC ('294) Patent Litigation, 831 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Bear Creek Technologies, Inc., ('722) Patent Litigation, 858 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Zoloft (Sertraline Hydrochloride) Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Royal Alliance Associates, Inc., Securities Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Automotive Wire Harness Systems Antitrust Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Wesson Oil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 818 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Gerova Financial Group, Ltd., Securities Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Wells Fargo Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation (No. III), 804 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Dial Complete Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Zimmer Nexgen Knee Implant Products Liability Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (10 of 28 actions in treansferree district); In re Google Android Consumer Privacy Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Certainteed Fiber Cement Siding Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re iPhone/iPad Application Consumer Privacy Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (noting eight actions pending in transferee district); In re: Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Electrical Receptacle Products Liability Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Operation of Missouri River System Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re New Motor Vehicles Canadian Export Antitrust Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Southwestern Life Ins. Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Sundstrand Data Control, Inc. Patent Litigation, 443 F. Supp. 1019, 1021 (J.P.M.L. 1978).

See In re McCormick & Company, Inc., Pepper Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re LTL Shipping Services Antitrust Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Avandia Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re African-American Slave Descendants Litigation, 231 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2002). See also In re Cathode Ray Tube (CRT) Antitrust Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (one action pending, Panel also notes that 16 of 26 potential tag-along actions pending in that district).

See, e.g., In re: Gold King Mine Release in San Juan County, Colorado, on August 5, 2015, 291 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (3 of 4 actions pending in district); In re Apple Inc. Device Performance Litigation, 291 F. Supp. 3d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (more than half the actions pending in district); In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 261 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (more than 60 of 161 cases in chosen transferee district); In re Atrium Medical Corp. C-Qur Mesh Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Invokana (Canagliflozin) Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (transfer to district with 37 actions pending); In re Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2016) (4 of 5 actions in district); In re Liquid Aluminum Sulfate Antitrust Litigation, 159 F. Supp. 3d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2016) (majority of pending actions in district); In re Walgreens Herbal Supplements Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Androgel Products Liability Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (significant number of actions pending in district); In re Incretin Mimetics Products Liability Litigation, F. Supp. 2d , 2013 WL 4838859 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (majority of actions in district); In re Unified Messaging Solutions LLC Patent Litigation, 883 F. Supp. 2d 1340 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (half of actions pending in district); In re Air Crash near Rio Grande, Puerto Rico, on December 3, 2008, 757 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (4 of 5 cases in district); In re Fosamax (Alendronate Sodium) Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 787 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (large number of actions in district); In re Optical Disk Drive Products Antitrust Litigation, 701 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2010) (most actions pending in district); In re Plasma-Derivative Protein Therapies Antitrust Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (7 of 10 actions); In re Air Crash near Clarence Center, New York, on February 12, 2009, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (18 of 21 actions); In re Androgel Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 655 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (6 of 8 actions); In re Wellpoint, Inc., Out-of-Network “UCR” Rates Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (3 of 5 actions); In re Blood Reagents Antitrust Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (“multiple” actions in district); In re Citigroup Inc. Securities Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (9 of 10 actions in district); In re Refrigerant Compressors Antitrust Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1320 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (19 actions in district; more than any other); In re Bill of Lading Transmission and Processing System Patent Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1341 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (6 of 8 cases pending in district); In re Oppenheimer Rochester Funds Group Securities Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (three of 13 actions pending in district); In re Puerto Rican Cabotage Antitrust Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (11 actions in transferee district, 10 before same judge); In re Wells Fargo Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (3 of 5 actions pending in district); In re FEMA Trailer Formaldehyde Products Liability Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (3 of 4); In re Radioshack Corp. “ERISA” Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (3 of 4); In re Sierra Wireless, Inc., Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Nortel Networks Corp. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1373, 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer of “lone outlying action” to join 28 filed in one other district); In re Parmalat Securities Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (3 of 4 actions pending in transferee district); In re High Sulfur Content Gasoline Products Liability Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 2d 755 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (4 of 5 actions pending in transferee district); In re Cotton Yarn Antitrust Litigation, 336 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Columbia University Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Helicopter Crash Near Meadview, Ariz., on Aug. 10, 2001, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Jetblue Airways Corp. Privacy Litigation, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Federal Home Loan Mort. Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation (No. II), 303 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Federal Home Loan Mort. Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation (No. II), 303 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Vitamins Antitrust Class Actions, 1999 WL 1211449 (D.D.C. 1999); In re Lutheran Brotherhood Variable Insurance Products Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 1999), withdrawn from bound volume; In re Phonometrics, Inc., Electronic Long Distance Call Cost Computers and Recorder Patent Litigation, 1997 WL 83673 (J.P.M.L. 1997) (20 of 21 actions); In re Air Crash Disaster at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Aug. 16, 1987, 674 F. Supp. 27 (J.P.M.L. 1987) (14 of 21 actions); In re Dow Chemical Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 650 F. Supp. 187, 189 (J.P.M.L. 1986) (6 of 14 actions); In re Continental Grain Co., Inc., 482 F. Supp. 330, 333 (J.P.M.L. 1979) (55 of 61 actions); In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 470 F. Supp. 855, 859 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Helicopter Crash Near Marsh Island, La., on December 8, 1977, 461 F. Supp. 675, 677 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Investors Funding Corp. of New York Securities Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 1199, 1203 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Amtrak Train Derailment at Frankewing, Tenn., on October 1, 1975, 431 F. Supp. 916, 918 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Olympia Brewing Co. Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 398, 402 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Folding Carton Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 384, 386 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Smith Patent Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 1403, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 406 F. Supp. 540, 543 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Gypsum Wallboard, 297 F. Supp. 1350 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (Panel noted and transferred cases to district where 94% of actions were filed); see also In re Water Meters, 304 F. Supp. 873 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (transfer to district where 71% of actions filed); In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239, 243 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (transfer to district where 9 of 13 actions pend).
See, e.g., In re: Equifax, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1322 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
See In re Air Crash Disaster at Bali, Indonesia, on April 22, 1974, 400 F. Supp. 1402, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See, e.g., In re Water Meters, 304 F. Supp. 873 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (transfer to district where 71% of actions filed). But see; In re Oxycontin Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 395 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (Panel suggests that while many “actions” favor transfer to a particular district, the fact they are represented by same law firm seems to militate against giving that factor great weight).
See, e.g., In re U-Haul Intern., Inc., 249 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).

See, e.g., In re Rail Freight Fuel Surcharge Antitrust Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (transfer to district where several actions are pending); In re Radiation Incident at Washington, D. C. on April 5, 1974, 400 F. Supp. 1404, 1406–1407 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (transfer to district where 5 of 6 actions are pending); In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239, 243 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (transfer to district where 9 of 13 actions pend).

See, e.g., In re Wesson Oil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 818 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (four of six actions pending in transferee district had been transferred there); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Dayton, Ohio, 310 F. Supp. 798, 799 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

The interaction of transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 and under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) is discussed in §§ 3:4 (power to transfer) and 5:3 (transfer). See In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404, 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1971) (transferor court's decision and reasons entitled to “great weight”). See also In re Athena Universal Life II Cost of Insurance Increase Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 3d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017); In re: Gerber Probiotic Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 899 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012); In re: Androgel Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 655 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
See, e.g., In re Monsanto Co. Genetically-Engineered Wheat Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (Panel cites fact five actions are pending in nearby districts to transferee district).
See In re Dow Chemical Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 650 F. Supp. 187, 189 (J.P.M.L. 1986).
The role of this factor is discussed in § 5:18.
